III. METHODOLOGY
05/13/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2020C0201018
05/13/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
With the Residential Director.
05/28/2020 Contact - Face to Face
Interview with Residents A, B, C., Staff 1, 2, 3, and the Facility
Nurse. Review of incident report. Review of Special investigation
Report #2019C0219049.
08/28/20 Exit with Director, Area Manager, Licensing Consultant Chris Barr.
Technical Assistance was given around avoiding restraining
residents on the wall.
ALLEGATION:
Resident was restrained after assaulting another resident. Resident sustained
a chipped tooth during the restraint.
INVESTIGATION:
 An incident report was submitted into MiSACWIS on December 18, 2019
regarding the allegation that occurred on December 16, 2019, incident
number 80210150. The incident report stated that while on Pod A, Resident
A and Resident B engaged in a verbal dispute. Resident A then assaulted
Resident B by striking him in the chest. Resident A was physically managed
by Staff 1 and placed on Seclusion status with the approval Shift Supervisor
A. Resident A sustained a chipped tooth during the restraint hitting the
control room window as he was being restrained from the rear while Resident
B did not incur any injuries. Both residents were examined by the Facility
Nurse.
2

 On May 12, 2020, another DHHS Worker sent an email to the DCWL Director
seeking information pertaining to the above allegation. The concern was that
Lincoln Center completed an internal investigation which Lincoln Center sent
the incident report to DHHS Supervisor about the incident but the allegation
was not sent to Child Welfare Licensing to open a complaint on the facility
base on the allegation received by DHHS during that time.
 On May12, 2020 the DCWL Director responded to the concern of another
DHHS Staff by stating that DCWL do not receive all incident reports from
Child Caring Institution (CCI). CCI’s are required in licensing rules to notify
DCWL of serious injury or illness of a resident requiring inpatient
hospitalization. The assigned Consultant for Lincoln Center was copied on
the email to determine whether an allegation was received of improper
restraint or behavior management related to this incident. The response
stated that based on the information provided, it was not clear whether there
were allegations related to this incident. At that time, an investigation was
assigned.
 Video surveillance of this incident was not reviewed base on the time frame
of the incident.
 I reviewed Special Investigation Report ##2019C0219049 dated October 14,
2019. This report provided technical assistance to Lincoln Center stating that
caution should be exercised when transferring a resident into the primary
restraint technique and while resisting and near a wall, as to prevent any
forceful contact. Positioning of a resident to a wall is reserved only for the
placement of mechanical restraints on and without force.
I interviewed Resident A, age 14, on May 28, 2020. He reported his peer, Resident
B was laughing at him for no apparent reason and he asked him to stop and
Resident B continued to laugh. He said he approached Resident B and told him that
he was going to give him five minutes to stop laughing or that he was going to tear
his Christmas decoration down from his door. He said Resident B continued to
laugh and he proceeded to try to rip the decoration from Resident B’s door but
before he could touch the door, Staff 1 grabbed him and threw him against the door
window causing him to chip his tooth. He said he already had a cap on that tooth
and when he was grabbed from behind under his arms, his arms went up in the air
and his face went into the door window causing the cap to fall off and his tooth being
chip. Resident A said he was not being aggressive towards his peer and he felt that
he should not have gotten restrained. He said he waited until the midnight shift
started and that is when he told the midnight shift supervisor about the incident and
his chip tooth. He said he received medical attention the next day. Resident A said
he did not chip his own tooth; he did not bang his head on the wall or acted
aggressively when he was restrained. He said he went into his room without
incident. He added no additional information.
I interviewed Resident B, age 17, on May 28, 2020. He reported he was laughing at
other peers on the pod and Resident A assumed he was laughing at him and told
3

him to stop laughing. He said he ignored Resident A and continued to laugh and
Resident A starting walking towards where he was standing which was by his
bedroom door. He said Resident A reached pass him and tried to tear his Christmas
decoration off his door. He said he pushed Resident A’s arm off his door and out of
nowhere, Staff 1 approached the two of them and restrained Resident A against the
wall. He said Resident A face was against the door window and that Staff 1 had
Resident A on the wall in a “Chicken wing” position. Resident B said he did not think
that the restraint of Resident A was appropriate or necessary. He denied that
Resident A was trying to assault him.
I interviewed Resident C, age 16, who was a witness to the incident between
Resident A and Staff 1. He said Resident B was laughing and Resident A told
Resident B to stop and that he was going to give Resident B something to laugh at.
He said Resident B continued to laugh and Resident A began approaching Resident
B and reached past pass Resident B trying to tear down Resident B’s decoration.
He said Staff 1 restrained Resident A and that he (Resident C) observed Resident A
face hit the window. He said Resident A was place in his room until showers.
Resident C said at no time did Resident A bang on his door or wall while in his
bedroom. Resident C reported that he felt the restraint of Resident A was not
necessary.
I interviewed Staff 1 on May 28, 2020. He reported that Resident A had been a
“terror” on the shift throughout the day. He said he was working another pod and
was sent over to work Resident A’s pod because there was two newer staff working
the pod. He said he exchanged positions with one of the newer staff because the
supervisor wanted a veteran staff to work the pod. He said that Resident A had
been written up because he was having a bad day. He said the Residential Director
had a meeting with that pod for over an hour trying to calm the group down. He said
Resident A was refusing to follow all directions from staff and continued to threaten
and attempted to hit Resident B. He said Resident A was going nuts trying to tear
down decorations from his peer doors that his peers had worked on all morning
decorating. He said Resident A approached Resident B and started fighting with
Resident B and that he (Staff 1) grabbed Resident A with Handle with Care
Techniques. He said he did not know how Resident A’s tooth got chip. He said from
his knowledge, Resident A’s face did not touch the wall or the window. He said
Resident A went into his room without struggle and was calm. He said Resident A
did not mention anything to him about his tooth being chipped. He reported the last
time he had a refresher course with the facility prescribed behavior management
techniques was last spring. Staff 1 reported he is not a full - time employee at the
facility but was an on-call staff.
I interviewed the Facility Nurse on May 28, 2020. She reported that Resident A’s
tooth was chipped prior to entering Lincoln Center on October 16, 2019. She said it
was documented in the nurse’s notes that Resident A entered the facility with a
small chip to his front corner tooth. She said Resident A did not complain about his
tooth between the months of October 16, 2019 to December 16, 2019. The nurse
4

said she went to examine Resident A the next day on December 17, 2020 due to
policy that anytime a resident is physically managed by staff, he is seen by the
facility nurse within twenty four hours, unless there is an emergency and he needs to
be seen sooner. The nurse said when she spoke to Resident A he told her that his
tooth had broken more than it was prior to his arrival. The nurse described Resident
A’s tooth as a small tooth chip in the front corner of his mouth. She said she made
appointments with the dentist for Resident A. She said the first time the dentist saw
Resident A was December 23, 2019. She said at time she had reviewed her notes
prior to the dentist appointment which stated he had the chipped tooth prior to this
placement at the facility. She said Resident A agreed that he had a chip tooth upon
arrival but stated that it was, “made larger,” by the restraint, The nurse reported that
Resident A was seen by the dentist on December 23, and he again received the
services of the dentist twice in January and once in February and March. received
the services of the dentist twice in January and once in February and March. The
dentist replaced the cap on the chipped tooth. She said she could not confirm that
Resident A’s tooth was chipped because of the restraint. She explained that a cap
usually has to be replaced every five years.
I interviewed Supervisor A regarding the allegation on May 28, 2020. He reported
he never saw the restraint and did not witness the incident. He added no additional
information.
I attempted contact with Staff 2 who was working the shift with Staff 1. He resigned
his position on February 26, 2020 and the agency reported his last telephone
number was not operational/disconnected.
I interviewed the Executive Director and she said I interviewed the Executive
Director and she said she did not feel this was an abuse/neglect case. She said the
information was inputted into MiSACWIS and all reporting source was informed of
the incident.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures regarding restraint. These
policies and procedures shall be available to all
residents, their families, and referring agencies.
5

ANALYSIS: The Supervisor reported he did not witness the restraint.
The Facility Nurse reported Resident A did not have any issues
with his tooth prior to being restrained on December 16, 2019.
She reported it was documented in the nurse’s notes that
Resident A entered the facility with a small chip to his front
corner tooth. She said Resident A did not complain about his
tooth between the months of October 16, 2019 to December 16,
2019. The nurse said she went to examine Resident A the next
day due to policy that anytime a resident is physically manage
by staff, he is seen by the facility nurse within twenty - four
hours, unless there is an emergency. The nurse said when she
spoke to Resident A he told her that his tooth had broken more.
The residents interviewed did not mention that the group was
having issues on the pod. All of the residents were consistent in
stating there was no fight between Resident A and Resident B.
All of the residents interviewed reported they felt the restraint of
Resident A by Staff 1 was not appropriate or necessary.
Special Investigation Report ##2019C0219049 dated October
14, 2019, provided technical assistance to Lincoln Center
stating that caution should be exercised when transferring a
resident into the primary restraint technique and while resisting
and near a wall, as to prevent any forceful contact. Positioning
of a resident to a wall is reserved only for the placement of
mechanical restraints on and without force.
It is not determined that Resident A’s tooth was chip during the
restraint that occurred on December 16, 2019, however, it is
determine that Resident A was inappropriately restrained.
Based on the interviews of the residents, and Special
Investigation #2019C0219049, the facility is in violation with not
following their written policies and procedures regarding
following their Handle with Care techniques.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon completion of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that Lincoln
Center License remain unchanged.
